title: Flamin’ Hot Cheetos are heating up the runway
text:
Popular snack sizzles at New York Fashion Week

Flamin’ Hot Cheetos are spicy as heck.

So hot, it seems, U.S. rapper Lil Xan allegedly had to go to the hospital last year because he ate too many.

“One helluva drug,” he posted on Instagram. Someone clearly had a snack attack.

According to research from 2016 by Ipsos (a company that asks people their opinions on products), more than two-thirds of what we eat is outside of traditional meals like breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Two-thirds of what we eat are, in fact, snacks.

That doesn’t mean two-thirds of our diet is chips, necessarily, but for some people, the chip family probably accounts for some of it.

So, being part of "Canadian Snacking Nation" (this is what Ipsos calls Canada), it probably wouldn’t totally shock you to think Frito-Lay (which makes Cheetos) could release a fashion collection, complete with accessories and makeup inspired by Cheeto dust.

Because that’s what it did earlier this week at New York Fashion Week.

The colours of the House of Flamin’ Haute collection were orange, red-orange, light orange and, well, you get the picture — it was very orange.

A close-up of dyed braids and a flaming top. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

Accessories were simple, like a single dangling earring that read Flamin’ Hot in the brand’s signature style.

There were also flames on shirts and braids dyed so red-orange, it looked like they had been rolled in Cheeto crumbs.

A flaming shirt-dress and a purse full of Cheetos. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

The collection is very on the nose. For example, the bottom of the shirt-dress above has flames on it because this is a collection inspired by Flamin’ Hot Cheetos.

Also, if you look closely, the purse the model is carrying is actually just a purse that’s filled with Cheetos — and the stylist threw a decal on top.

Flame eye makeup on a model at the House of Flamin Haute show at New York Fashion Week. (Dave Kotinsky/Getty Images)

There was a lot of attention to detail with the show’s beauty looks.

Some models had flame makeup on their eyelids, which complemented the Cheetos hair clips and hair jewellery.

Cheetos-themed braid charms on a model backstage. (Dave Kotinsky/Getty Images)

But, really, people wondered why this was even happening.

Another Twitter user quickly replied: “because why not.”

But it wasn't all positivity.

A twitter user posted a GIF that reads "I am...disgusted."

It’s a good question, though. Why did this happen?

Well, for brand awareness, it seems — which is primarily why any designer or brand holds a fashion show.

Also, in this case, it was an opportunity to have influencers design pieces inspired by their favourite snack.

But if you are at all interested in owning any of these pieces, you can’t.

As of now, they are one-of-a-kind.

That doesn’t mean they aren’t fun to look at.

It does, however, mean no red-orange bandana with a sticker on it for you.

A model with hair that looks like Cheeto powder. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

No hyper-realistic Flamin’ Hot Cheeto scrunchies, either.

Two models in their orange gear on the runway. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

No jumpsuit with giant decal on the back.

The back detail of an orange Cheetos jumpsuit. (Dave Kotinsky/Getty Images)

You could make this at home!

A close-up of bag that holds a bag of Cheetos. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

Just find a see-through bag and tape an open bag of Cheetos inside.

Same goes for this backpack.

A bag full of snacks. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

Find a see-through backpack and fill it with Cheetos and put stickers on it. If you wanted to do that, for some reason.

This DIY masterpiece would be a great art project to try at home.

A full dress embellished with cheesy and spicy snacks. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

This fashion show is an example of a brand wanting attention, for sure. But was there a need for it? There are defintely a lot of fans who would say yes.

For some, Cheetos are an emotional experience.

A close-up of dyed braids and a flaming top. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

Cheetos are so beloved, they are finding their way into unusual food pairings, like ice cream.

A close-up of dyed braids and a flaming top. (Ilya S. Savenok/Getty Images)

And a movie is being made about the janitor who developed the recipe for Flamin’ Hot Cheetos.

If for whatever reason, you wanted a Flamin’ Hot Cheetos bundt cake, here it is:

Some people just have a hard time saying no.

Cheetos culture is real. But is it spectacular? Or does it just make your tummy hurt?

What's Fire This Week is your weekly look at what everyone's talking about.
description: Cheetos and Frito-Lay House of Flamin’ Haute Collection at New York Fashion Week.
